review.title: Word Embeddings to Enhance Twitter Gang Member Profile Identification
review.abstract: Gang affiliates have joined the masses who use social media to share thoughts and actions publicly. Interestingly, they use this public medium to express recent illegal actions, to intimidate others, and to share outrageous images and statements. Agencies able to unearth these profiles may thus be able to anticipate, stop, or hasten the investigation of gang-related crimes. This paper investigates the use of word embeddings to help identify gang members on Twitter. Building on our previous work, we generate word embeddings that translate what Twitter users post in their profile descriptions, tweets, profile images, and linked YouTube content to a real vector format amenable for machine learning classification. Our experimental results show that pre-trained word embeddings can boost the accuracy of supervised learning algorithms trained over gang members social media posts.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: Researchers have begun to investigate the use of social media by gang members and have noticed the importance of identifying the Twitter profiles of gang members a priori [PEB13, WDSD15]. Prior to analyzing any textual context retrieved from their social media posts, we know that a post originates from a gang member could help systems better understand the message conveyed by that post. Wijeratne et al. developed a framework to analyze what gang members post on social media [WDSD15]. Their framework could only extract social media posts from self-identified gang members by looking for pre-identified band names in a user's Twitter profile description. Patton et al. developed a method to collect tweets from a group of gang members operating in Detroit, MI [Pat15]. Their approach required the word names of gang members to be known beforehand, and the profiles collection was often localized to a small town in a small area.

sections.heading: 3 Word Embeddings
sections.text: A word embedding model is a neural network that learns rich representations of words in a text corpus. It takes data from a large, n-dimensional "word space" (where n is the number of unique words in a corpus) and learns a transformation of the data into a lower k-dimensional space of real numbers. This transformation is developed in such a way that similarities between the k-dimensional vector representation of two words reflect semantic relationships between the words themselves. This semantics is not captured by typical lexicon or n-gram models for classification tasks on text data [MYZ13, MSC + 13].Word embeddings have resulted in the state of the art results in many sequential learning tasks [LBH15]. Indeed, word embedding learning is an important step for many statistical language modeling tasks in text systems.

sections.heading: 4 Evaluation
sections.text: We evaluate the performance of using Word embedding to detect gang profiles on Twitter. First, we discuss the data set, learning algorithms, and baseline comparison models used in the experiments. Then, we discuss the 10-fold cross-validation experiments and the evaluation matrices used. Finally, we present the results of the experiments.

sections.heading: 4.1 Evaluation setup
sections.text: We are looking at a dataset of curated gang and non-gang members with Twitter profiles gathered from our previous work [BWDS16]. It was developed by querying the API4 Followerwonk web service with location-neutral seeds that are known to be used by gang members in their Twitter profiles in the US. However, the dataset was further expanded by examining the friends, followers and retweet networks of the gang member profile found by searching for seed words. Specific details about our data shortening process are discussed in [BWDS16]. Ultimately, this dataset consists of 400 gang member profiles and 2,865 non-gang member profiles. For each user profile, we have up to most of the current 3,200 tweets from their Twitter timelines, profile description text, profile and cover images, as well as the comments and video descriptions for each of them to be shared on YouTube, YouTube.

sections.heading: 4.2 10-fold cross validation
sections.text: We performed 10-fold cross-validation experiments to evaluate the performance of our models. We used all of the Twitter profiles in the dataset to conduct experiments with the five methods we used to combine word embedding vectors; for each of the five vector combination methods (as mentioned in Section 3.2), we trained classifiers using every learning algorithm we considered; in each fold, the learning sentence was used to generate word embedding vectors, which were then used to calculate characteristics for both the training set and the test set. For each 10-fold cross-validation experiment, we report three evaluation metrics for the "gait" (positive) and "non-gait" (negative), namely the precision = tp / (tp + fp), recall = tp / (tp + fn) and F1 score = 2 (precision) recall / (precision) recall, with the true number of positives, the false number of positives, the false number of positives, and the n in the negative number.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: Using a Twitter dataset consisting of 400 profiles of gang members and 2,865 profiles of non-gang members, we trained word embedding models based on tweets, profile descriptions, emojis, images and videos shared on Twitter (text features extracted from images and videos), and then used pre-trained word embedding models to train supervised machine learning classifiers that performed superior compared to the state-of-the-art base models reported in the literature. We plan to further expand our work by building our own image classification system specifically designed to identify images frequently shared by gang members, such as firearms, gang handmarks, stacks of cash and medicines. We would also like to experiment with the automatic construction of dictionaries containing band names and band-related slang using crowd-sourced knowledge bases such as WikiHip6.
